intro: Lagotis glauca subsp. minor, commonly known as the lesser bluebell, is a herbaceous perennial native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It features striking blue to purple flowers that bloom in early spring, often in clusters at the ends of its stems. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and has narrow, grass-like leaves that are arranged in a basal rosette. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in alpine meadows and rocky habitats. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
